sentences.text: Okay, guys.
So in this next video, we have Hal, who's in the blue over here.
And so at this point, we're kind of getting to some of the more advanced players, I would say, in this course.
So at this level, these players are kind kind of if you watch how play, you can tell he's got the technique down.
Right.
He's not really making any obvious technical errors, I can see.
So at this point, when you get more advanced, it's less about doing the movements correctly and it's more about optimising it and getting faster and being more explosive.
Right.
So I've watched this whole video, and I've also had Ben Beckman from the diving master class course take a look at it.
And basically the biggest thing for you, how that you could improve on is your explosiveness.
Right.
It feels almost like, again, this is just for everyone else watching this, this is a bit more advanced.
So if you're still at the stage where you're learning technique, then don't worry about this too much and focus just on getting the technique down.
But for your players who are a bit more advanced, something you really want to think about is explosiveness.
And what I mean by that is you'll hear Jill Clarke say this quite a lot, but it's the ability to inject speed into the rally.
So you might be playing the rally like you are here at a standard pace.
Right.
But then when you see the opening, you then inject that explosive speed and pace to change the tide of the Valley in your favour.
Right.
And this is something that pro players do extremely well.
So just to show you a few examples of what I mean, this is one good example here.
Right.
You see that?
So what happens here is you kind of force him kind of under pressure.
He's taking it fairly relatively deep forehand.
He plays a week clear.
But here you're very passive.
Right.
So let's just quickly see what you do.
You don't really do much with the shuttle.
Right.
You play a fairly decent shot.
But look at the position you're in here, just here.
Right.
This is a perfect chance for you to bounce onto the shuttle.
If you're quick enough, you can jump explosively, get to the shuttle high and early, and then you can play like a really aggressive clip, smash, crosscourt straight or whatever.
But you can play really aggressive.
And that's a great chance to inject your pace into the rally and control the rally.
But instead, you kind of just let them get away with it.
Right.
You play a very neutral shot.
That's one example.
And then also, it's not just on the attack.
It's actually also on the defence as well.
And I'll show you what I mean by that.
Okay.
So here's a good example.
So you play your clear, you recover back to the middle, and then when the smash comes, it's almost as if the entire thing is one speed, right?
You've got one speed and you keep that for the entire rally.
But what you need to be doing is realising that in a situation where you're defending a smash like that, you can't just keep that speed.
You need to inject that sudden pace into it and get to that shuttle as quickly as you physically can.
Right.
So you almost seem kind of relaxed when you do that.
When you see the smash, you're kind of relaxed and you're not moving with the appropriate urgency.
I think you can see what I mean.
And the best way to improve this, because your technique is fine.
It's just getting in those reps, getting in that shadow, practise, getting multi feed if you can, and just working on that urgency.
Remember, you want to get that racket to the shuttle as quickly as possible.
And clearly here you're kind of a bit more relaxed.
A part of this lack of explosiveness, both on the attack and the defence, is because you're a little flat footed and you're not always split stepping.
So if you just watch this again real quick.
Right.
And the reason I bring it up is if you compare that to a rally that takes place later on, you do actually split step and you're a lot faster.
Yeah, this one that looks a lot better.
So if you just watch those two back, I think you should be able to tell the difference between what you're doing.
But in general, in a lot of these valleys, you're a little flat footed and that kind of agility hinders your ability to inject that pace.
So the final thing is that on a lot of these overhead shots, you're not really bringing your right foot forward and that's slowing down your recovery.
So let me just show you what I mean.
So you start here and this is all fine, right.
Then as you hit, you've actually hit the shuttle already and your right foot is only really coming out to the side, and then afterwards you're bringing it forwards.
So maybe if you watch this, you might have actually not noticed it, because it's like you're kind of tricking yourself.
But what this needs to be is one smooth, fluid motion of the legs with the shuttle, right.
So the right leg comes forward with the shuttle.
What you're doing is you're only doing half of the movement stopping and then doing the other half of the movement.
And that kind of defeats the point.
That's just one example.
And there are a few other examples in this clip where it's probably more obvious, it's even more so obvious that you're not fully rotating through on your scissor kicks.
So just keep that in mind.
Again, that's probably the biggest technical error you have.
And just get those repetitions of practising and it's really just a mental thing of rewiring your brain, and that's going to help a lot with recovery.
Okay.
So I hope that helps helps.
How and I would like to thank you for being the only person who edited their clips.
So it's just the action.
You've edited all the downtime.
I appreciate that so much.
All right.
I hope that helped and let's move on to the next video.
